Short version:Moai Better Blues is probably the strangest episode of the season with its backwards solutions and disjointed puzzle setups, but it also has ridiculous amounts of entertainingly crazy dialogues.Long version:Sam & Max arrive home from the North Pole—where they may have caused some irreparable damages to the spirit of Christmas in the last episode—in time to get entangled in a strange series of events involving Bermuda triangles (yes, plural) and the Eastern Isle.Therefore, the special setting of the second episode is a nice tropical island, where we meet quite a few new characters, including several historical figures (and not just Abraham Lincoln, who spends a nice picnic there with his girlfriend).Their banter is the high point of this episode, because the puzzles are strangely bland and really insanely difficult at the same time. Bland, because most of the subtasks feel like a random series of puzzles with little cohesion (for example, the C.O.P.S. minigame here makes no sense, and not in a good Sam & Max crazy way). And difficult, because the lack of a clear theme means there is very little to go on besides some of the hints hidden in dialogues. It is also the first time in this series where time becomes a part of the puzzles, setting off the insofar laid back, casual nature.I couldn’t say Moai Better Blues is bad, since it has the true essence of these characters, down to the sometimes almost cruel comedy bits and the really wonky banter and situations. If for nothing else, it should be played for its script.
